reviewText: Don't do drugs and play this game.

Certainly one of the most unsettling games I've played in recent memory. You start the game thrust into what can best be described as a very weird and strangely vacant city with awesome architecture. The devs, Limasse Five, bang on nail a feeling between alien and familiar that kept me simmering at a creeped out foreboding.

You can tell from the screens how visually strong the game is, but it's more than worth noting the fantastic sound design. Environmental sound effects carry realistically in huge open spaces and tight air vents alike and the music tracks are licensed from several professional artists that basically make the city feel even more alien, even more threatening and even more awesome at just the right moments.

In terms of gameplay, make your way through the city! The story as such is very nondescript and you're basically relying on your own interpretation of your surroundings to create whatever you like in your head. Limasse have said the game is meant to evoke a strong feeling of loneliness and that's very much a realised theme. For the most part, NaissanceE is a fairly challengeless game but certain infrequent sections will test your first person platforming skills. Though in my experience checkpoints during these bits were reasonably well spaced and aren't too much of a barrier.

In general, the atmosphere and art of this game is astoundingly good.

It's a shame the gameplay ranges from pretty decent at best to mediocre and, at a few points, outright terrible.

The breathing mechanic, I like. It adds a layer to the gameplay that's just a simple thing to manage while you do other platforming stuff. It never really gets in the way.

Each chapter is kind of its own thing, chapter 1 does a lot of vision-based puzzles, chapter 2 is descending a massive area and might be almost half the game's length by itself, chapter 3 has some really tightrope-y platforming going on, chapter 4 is... special, though one of its segments is easily the worst moment of the game. Chapters 5 and 6... basically don't exist, and chapter 7 is a kind of annoying final boss" sort of thing-y. The general vibe of the game is a 3D platforming and kind of walking-simulator-but-not-really and there's some puzzles along the way.

I was expecting more. but the games video was grainy and the game has the look and feel as if it was created in Blender in five minutes.
Amazing what they did with mostly lighting effects, mood, speed, and shapes.  Very surprising game.

I would love to reccomend this game as it has a beautiful atmosphere and some cute little puzzles to solve.

However while the light and dark aspect of it looks great, once the lights began shifting and moving, I found myself getting motion sickness. I was struggling too much just to look at the game, let alone solve any of it's puzzles.

If you have a strong stomach and don't have epilepsy, I would 100% reccomend it, but for everyone else, you may need a bucket to finish this one.

I love the aesthetics in this game!

If you like the radicalist, feverish dreams of futurist architecture, Tsutomu Nihei's body of work (Blame!, Knights of Sidonia), Blade Runner and moody minimalist moodpieces, NaissanceE is definitely for you.\n\nSome sequence do break the flow and immersion by making you die over and over on a simple timing puzzle, but the sights and sound are well worth the bother in the end.

Long version: Some parts took me a couple of tries to figure out, but eventually even I completed the game. I don't consider myself an amazing gamer or anything like that, but i felt this game was challenging enough for the average gamer to complete.
I don't think the game was ment to be a purely exploration based game (probably why the game is getting any negativity at all since it was labled as one). Otherwise why would they even include death as a response to going the wrong way or making a huge mistake? The trial and error, the easter eggs and hidden dead ends... The fact that the only way to get a story, or rather an idea as to what is going on, is through extrapulating what the environment shows you, makes the game that much more compelling. yes you could add things to make it easier, but that doesn't always make a game better. The satisfaction of completion well outweighed the learning curve the game presented.

Short version: I don't believe this game is for everyone, but i do believe anyone who can understand it's basic mechanics can complete it. Kind of like an easier platformer version of the dark souls series, the challenge and reward of figuring it all out yourself is just apart of it.
